feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.summary: Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Montgomery

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 16 at 6:25PM EST by NWS Caribou ME
entry.summary:
At 624 PM EST...An area of heavy snow was along a line extending from 8 miles southeast of Lakeville to 11 miles southwest of Meddybemps to 14 miles southeast of Cutler...and moving east AT 15 MPH.
Locations impacted include... Calais, Machias, Lubec, Eastport, Danforth, Vanceboro, Perry, Pembroke, Princeton, Jonesboro, Cutler, Springfield, Topsfield, Meddybemps, Grand Lake Stream, Lakeville, Lincoln, Fowler Township, Dyer Township, and Codyville Plantation.
This includes the following highways... US Highway 1 between Machias and Danforth. State Highway 9 between Wesley and Calais.
* Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour are occurring in this area of heavy snow.
Rapid visibility reduction and potentially icy roads could lead to accidents. Consider delaying travel until the area of heavy snow passes your location. If traveling pull off to a safe location.
To report impactful winter weather, contact the National Weather Service office in Caribou, by calling 1-800-909- 5970 or visit https://inws.ncep.noaa.gov/report.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Central Penobscot; Interior Hancock; Central Washington; Coastal Washington; Northern Washington

cap:parameter.value: An area of heavy snow will affect Washington...northeastern Hancock and east central Penobscot Counties

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 16 at 2:13PM AKST until November 17 at 5:00AM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Mixed precipitation. Additional snow accumulations up to 1 to 3 inches and trace ice accumulations. Winds gusting as high as 35 to 40 mph.
* WHERE...Interior Kuskokwim Delta.
* WHEN...Until 5 AM AKST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Visibilities reduced to one half mile or less due to blowing snow. Travel could be very difficult.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 AM AKST MONDAY

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 AM AKST MONDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 16 at 2:09PM AKST until November 17 at 6:00PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...SNOW MONDAY INTO TUESDAY MORNING...
.Monday another front will move across the Panhandle bringing more extensive snow back to the north. Current forecast has confidence of 2 to 4 inches of snowfall in the lower sections of the Klondike Highway, and near 4 to 6 inches for White Pass, for a 12 hour period Monday morning through Monday evening. Light accumulations are expected Monday night into Tuesday morning, up to one inch.
Light snow will begin again early Monday morning. Heaviest rates will come in Monday afternoon, likely sometime near 3pm to 6pm, with a few hours of 0.5 to 0.75 inch per hour rates. After the front, rates decrease with persistent light snow into Tuesday morning.
* WHAT...Snow expected. Snow accumulations ranging from 4 to 6 inches.
* WHERE...Klondike Highway east of MP 6.
* WHEN...From 6 AM to 6 PM AKST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heaviest snow is expected Monday afternoon with rates up to 0.75 inches per hour.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Municipality of Skagway

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 6 AM TO 6 PM AKST MONDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 16 at 1:50PM AKST until November 19 at 3:00PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow and gusty winds expected. Total snow accumulations between 4 and 8 inches. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills, Lower Yukon River, and Yukon Delta Coast.
* WHEN...Until 3 PM AKST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be difficult. Gusty winds combined with snow could lead to significant reductions in visibility. Localized blizzard conditions possible at times.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...As the first system moves north, conditions may briefly improve ahead of a second system moving in midweek.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills; Yukon Delta Coast; Lower Yukon River

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM AKST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 16 at 5:46PM EST by NWS Binghamton NY
entry.summary:
Lake effect snow will continue to organize across Southern Cayuga, Onondaga, Tompkins, Madison and Cortland Counties this evening. Road temperatures will continue to fall this evening with snow beginning to stick and cause slippery roads.
If you are traveling this evening, watch out for slippery roads especially later this evening. Higher terrain areas will see the slippery roads first.
Monitor NOAA Weather Radio for the latest information, forecasts and warnings.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Cayuga; Onondaga; Tompkins; Madison; Cortland

cap:parameter.value: Lake Effect Snow will continue to increase in central NY this evening

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 16 at 5:27PM EST until November 17 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Binghamton NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Lake effect snow. Additional snow accumulations 3 to 7 inches. Highest amounts will be over the higher terrain. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Cortland, Madison, Onondaga, Southern Cayuga, and Tompkins Counties in central NY.
* WHEN...Until 7 PM EST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday morning and evening commutes. Gusty winds could bring down tree branches.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Lake effect snow will become more organized downwind of Lake Ontario in the advisory area tonight and last into Monday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Cayuga; Onondaga; Tompkins; Madison; Cortland

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM EST MONDAY

entry.summary:

* WHERE...Southern Mountains.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 16 at 1:34PM PST until November 18 at 7:00AM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the first Winter Weather Advisory, tapering snow. Snow accumulations up to one inch. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph. For the second Winter Weather Advisory, snow. Snow accumulations of 7 to 15 inches above 8500 feet. Snow accumulations of 2 to 6 inches below 8500 feet. Winds gusting as high as 40 mph as the precipitation arrives, but will start to taper once snow begins to fall.
* WHERE...Mono County.
* WHEN...For the first Winter Weather Advisory, until 4 PM PST this afternoon. For the second Winter Weather Advisory, from 7 AM Monday to 7 AM PST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous. Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday morning and evening commutes. Gusty winds could bring down tree branches.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Mono

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 PM PST THIS AFTERNOON... ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 7 AM MONDAY TO 7 AM PST TUESDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 16 at 3:20PM CST by NWS Bismarck ND
entry.summary: Patchy dense fog will occasionally reduce visibility to one quarter mile over parts of Williams, Mountrail, and Divide Counties through early evening. Motorists should be prepared for rapidly changing conditions and use extra caution traveling. Use low beam headlights and be extra cautious at intersections and railroad crossings.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 16 at 2:59PM EST by NWS Wilmington OH
entry.summary:
A combination of wind gusts of between 20 to 30 mph and relative humidity values of 20 to 25 percent will create an elevated fire weather danger this afternoon into very early evening.
Take precautions if planning to do any outdoor burning today as conditions are favorable for fire spread.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued November 16 at 12:47PM EST until November 17 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Albany NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Moderate to heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations between 7 and 14 inches, mainly near and north of Route 28.
* WHERE...Northern Herkimer County.
* WHEN...Until 7 PM EST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Roads will likely become slick and hazardous from moderate to heavy snow falling today through Monday. Visibilities may drop below 1 mile due to moderate to heavy snowfall and blowing snow. Travel could be difficult.

entry.summary:

* WHERE...Chautauqua and Cattaraugus Counties. The greatest accumulations will be across the higher terrain inland from the Lake Erie shore. Accumulations close to the lake including along the NYS Thruway will be less than an inch.
* WHEN...Until 1 PM EST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Travel will be difficult with snow covered roads and poor visibility. The hazardous conditions will impact the Monday morning commute.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued November 16 at 7:53AM PST until November 16 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Hanford CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...A portion of central California, including the following areas, Fresno-Tulare Foothills, Fresno-Tulare Lower Sierra, Kern River Valley, Mariposa Madera Foothills, Mariposa-Madera Lower Sierra, Piute Walker Basin, South End Sierra Foothills and South End of the Lower Sierra.
* WHEN...Until 4 PM PST this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Low-water crossings may be flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Heavy rain will continue across the watch area. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 16 at 9:50AM EST by NWS Morristown TN
entry.summary:
The combination of gusty northwesterly winds, and low afternoon relative humidities will lead to an elevated fire risk this afternoon, even despite the light rain early this morning. Northwest winds will be sustained at 15 to 20 mph gusting 25 to 30 mph, which could allow for fires to become uncontrolled. Relative humidity values will also drop into the mid to upper 20s.
Please refer to your local burn permitting authorities on whether you can burn today. Use extreme caution when burning as fires may get out of hand quickly in these conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Claiborne; Hancock; Hawkins; Sullivan; Johnson; Grainger; Hamblen; Northwest Cocke; Cocke Smoky Mountains; Northwest Greene; Southeast Greene; Washington; Unicoi; Northwest Carter; Southeast Carter; Jefferson; Lee; Wise; Scott; Russell; Washington

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 16 at 3:36AM EST by NWS Northern Indiana
entry.summary:
A combination of northwest wind gusts to 20 to 30 mph and minimum relative humidity values of 20 to 40 percent will create an elevated fire danger today. The lowest humidity values (around 20-25 percent) will be along and south of US 30, west of I 69- especially near White County, IN.
Furthermore, given the extreme drought in northwest Ohio and portions of north-central Indiana, fine fuels-such as grasses and leaf litter-are dry and susceptible to ignition. This is especially the case in areas that did not receive as much precipitation or snowfall in the last event.
Take precautions if planning to do any outdoor burning today as conditions are favorable for fire spread.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Elkhart; Lagrange; Steuben; Noble; De Kalb; Starke; Pulaski; Marshall; Fulton; Whitley; Allen; White; Cass; Miami; Wabash; Huntington; Wells; Adams; Grant; Blackford; Jay; Northern La Porte; Eastern St. Joseph; Northern Kosciusko; Southern La Porte; Western St. Joseph; Southern Kosciusko; Williams; Fulton; Defiance; Henry; Paulding; Putnam; Van Wert; Allen

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 16 at 3:09AM EST by NWS Indianapolis IN
entry.summary:
A combination of wind gusts of around 20 to 25 mph and relative humidity values of 15 to 25 percent will create an elevated fire weather danger this afternoon.
Recent dry weather has left fine fuels, such as grasses and leaf litter dry and susceptible to ignition. Take precautions if planning to do any outdoor burning today as conditions are favorable for fire spread.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Carroll; Warren; Tippecanoe; Clinton; Howard; Fountain; Montgomery; Boone; Tipton; Hamilton; Madison; Delaware; Randolph; Vermillion; Parke; Putnam; Hendricks; Marion; Hancock; Henry; Vigo; Clay; Owen; Morgan; Johnson; Shelby; Rush; Sullivan; Greene; Monroe; Brown; Bartholomew; Decatur; Knox; Daviess; Martin; Lawrence; Jackson; Jennings

cap:parameter.value: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH THIS EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 16 at 2:43AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
A dry air mass moves into the area behind a departing cold front today. With warm temperatures remaining in place, relative humidity values will drop into the 20 to 25 percent range across the North Carolina foothills and Piedmont. Northwest wind gusts to around 25 mph will continue into the afternoon as well. The combination of low relative humidity and gusty winds will lead to Increased Fire Danger across these areas this afternoon and evening.
Please refer to your local burn permitting authorities on whether you can burn today. If you do burn, use extreme caution since fires can quickly get out of hand under these conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Alexander; Iredell; Davie; Catawba; Rowan; Cleveland; Lincoln; Gaston; Mecklenburg; Cabarrus; Union; Caldwell Mountains; Greater Caldwell; Burke Mountains; Greater Burke; McDowell Mountains; Eastern McDowell; Rutherford Mountains; Greater Rutherford; Polk Mountains; Eastern Polk

cap:parameter.value: INCREASED FIRE DANGER THIS AFTERNOON AND EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 16 at 1:26AM EST by NWS Morristown TN
entry.summary:
The combination of gusty northwesterly winds, and low afternoon relative humidities will lead to an elevated fire risk this afternoon, even despite the light rain early this morning. Northwest winds will be sustained at 15 to 20 mph gusting to 25 to 30 mph, which could allow for fires to become uncontrolled.
Please refer to your local burn permitting authorities on whether you can burn today. Use extreme caution when burning as fires may get out of hand quickly in these conditions.
